Question: Design instructional content on virtualization, emphasizing the operational principles of full, para-, and hardware-supported virtualization, including a breakdown of hypervisor types and associated performance trade-offs.

Core_Concepts.Definition: Uses isolation mechanisms to provide users with virtual environments similar to a dedicated server.
Key_Points: Isolates users in virtual environments similar to a dedicated server.
Requires the guest operating system to be modified to use a set of hooks to improve machine execution simulation.
Core_Concepts.Significance_Detail: Operating system level virtualisation is important because it allows multiple users to run their own isolated environments on the same physical hardware, increasing resource utilization and efficiency.
Core_Concepts.Strengths: This type of virtualisation can improve security by isolating user environments from each other.
Core_Concepts.Weaknesses: The guest operating system needs to be modified, which may introduce compatibility issues.

Core_Concepts.Definition: Requires the guest operating system to be modified to use a set of hooks to improve machine execution simulation – Para-virtualisation enabled by Type1 Hypervisor.
Key_Points: Guest operating system is modified to use hooks for improved machine execution simulation.
Core_Concepts.Significance_Detail: Para-virtualization is important because it allows the guest operating system to be more compatible with the underlying hardware, reducing performance overhead.
Core_Concepts.Strengths: This type of virtualisation can improve performance by using hooks for improved machine execution simulation.
Core_Concepts.Weaknesses: The guest operating system needs to be modified, which may introduce compatibility issues.

Core_Concepts.Definition: Fully simulates all the hardware of the underlying device by providing a virtual machine.
Key_Points: Simulates all the hardware of the underlying device.
Core_Concepts.Significance_Detail: Full virtualization is important because it allows any operating system to run on the virtual machine without modification, providing greater flexibility and compatibility.
Core_Concepts.Strengths: This type of virtualisation can support a wide range of guest operating systems without modification.
Core_Concepts.Weaknesses: Full virtualization may have higher performance overhead compared to other types of virtualisation.

Overall_Summary: Virtualization is the process of creating isolated environments on a single physical hardware, allowing multiple users or applications to run simultaneously. Operating system level virtualization, para-virtualization, and full virtualization are different approaches to achieve this goal, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.
